title: Title VIII - Lease
coverage: General Provisions, Rural and Urban Lease

articles.rule: A contract of lease may be of things, or of work and service.
In the lease of things, one party gives the enjoyment or use of a thing for a certain price and period. No lease exceeding 99 years is valid.
Lease of work or service requires execution of work or rendering of service for a price, without principal-agent relationship.
Consumable goods cannot be leased unless for exhibition or as accessories to an industrial establishment.
The lessee cannot assign the lease without the consent of the lessor unless stipulated otherwise.
The lessee may sublet the leased property in whole or in part if there is no express prohibition.
The lessor must deliver the property fit for its intended use, make necessary repairs, and ensure peaceful enjoyment during the lease.
The lessee must pay rent, use the property diligently, and pay expenses for the deed of lease.
The lessee may suspend rent payment if the lessor fails to make necessary repairs or ensure peaceful enjoyment.
If either party fails to comply with obligations, the aggrieved party may seek rescission and/or damages.
If the leased dwelling poses imminent danger to life or health, the lessee may immediately terminate the lease.
The lessee must return the leased property upon termination, except for ordinary wear and tear or inevitable loss.
A lease for a definite period ends on the day fixed without need of demand.
Continued possession for 15 days with the lessor's consent results in an implied new lease.
The lessor may eject the lessee for expiration, non-payment, contract violation, or improper use of property.
If time and place of rent payment are not stipulated, legal provisions and local custom apply.
If no period is fixed, lease duration depends on rent payment frequency, subject to court determination.
